newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: ARGENTINE MIDDLE CLASS BENEFITS MOST UNDER MENEM.
newsitem.headline: ARGENTINE MIDDLE CLASS BENEFITS MOST UNDER MENEM.

text.p: Argentina's middle class has seen its income grow 60.3 percent since the start of President Carlos Menem's administration in 1989, more than the rich or poor, an official survey said.
However, the purchasing power of the middle class is still lower than in 1986, according to the data by the INDEC statistics institute.

The survey, published in the local daily Ambito Financiero, shows the lower class is faring worst. While their salaries rose 68 percent between 1990 and 1994, they are still 25 percent worse off than in 1996.
The income of the upper class rose 51 percent since 1989 and they are now very near 1986 levels.
The gap between the recovery rate of lower class wages and middle and upper class wages between 1989-1997 is 10 percent.
